description:
I managed to pick up an RX 9070 XT and I'm really impressed with it, especially at the price. I've been benchmarking like a mad man to get everything for you guys. We going over the RTX 5070 Ti, 5070, FSR 4, video encoding, the MASSIVE Ray Tracing improvements! The GPU has changed everything.

If you wanna try getting the RX 9070 or 9070 XT, here are some links:

___ RX 9070 XT ___ 
Amazon: https://amzn.to/3FeK1M0
Newegg: https://howl.link/h8w4a5hksrt8l
BestBuy: https://howl.link/ysj5suk3gsu0z

___ RX 9070 ___ 
Amazon: https://amzn.to/41Msvat
Newegg: https://howl.link/uiqcd582f8dp4
BestBuy: https://howl.link/23oy6yzsnt0d0

(links above are affiliate links! commissions go to support the channel! f honey)


==JOIN THE DISCORD!==
https://discord.gg/xbVEkhPJ72

HUB: https://youtu.be/gWIIA-a9Q9A?si=14OB6Z9LYeICt-pD

https://videocardz.com/newz/nvdia-reportedly-pushes-geforce-rtx-5060-ti-back-to-mid-april-rtx-5060-to-mid-may
https://linustechtips.com/topic/1295515-amd-radeon-drivers-fking-suck/

0:00- I LOVE NVIDIA
0:49- Wait.
2:00- AMD Value
2:35- the competitor is uhhhh....
3:20- RX 9070 XT vs RTX 5070 Ti
8:16- AMD Ray Tracing has come SO FAR
10:08- 9070 XT acts more expensive than it really is
11:30- vs RTX 5070 (4070 Super Duper lol)
15:30- FSR 4 is... wow
17:56- FSR 4 downsides
21:00- RX 9070 XT improvements are HUGE
22:20- Supply

comments.text:
who spends 800€+ on a GPU and doesnt at least have a Quest 2? They can be had for 150€
And why won't you do any testing of it? Is it because that every generation of AMD cards for the last decade has sucked for it?
Wait, thats not true. the RX 400/500 were half-decent value VR cards.

And I mean, go ahead, get a Quest, since its the only headset that runs half decent on AMD cards, now that they fixed their encoders on the 9000 series.
But go ahead and get a Valve Index. Surely, that should work, right? But it won't 😂
And god save you if you actually get some balls and buy a real headset like a Pimax

Similarly, why don't you show off the new Half Life 2 RTX demo?
Ray tracing is an open standard, its not exclusive to nvidia, never was. Its just part of the Directx12 standard. AMD could've been keeping up sooner, if they wanted to. They chose not to.

Also, your 1% low findings weren't seen across other testers, so, you likely just screwed it up, and I hope you'll correct your findings.

Or do you prefer them this way?

comments.text: Y do all reviewers speak in percentages? F percentages. All percentages do in the case that most reviwers uses, just make the cards seem soo much better than they really are.. just FPS increases is what you should be saying. I get it, there is a need for percentages to show overall generational improvements but just have slides at the end with percentage but everything else, state the actual FPS differences in averages, overall (with RT), and 1% lows.. IF you say 80% difference, I will automatically take that as 80FPS difference. there is mass confusion so stop and focus on actual FPS!!!

comments.text: I have an RX7900XTX in my Linux gaming setup.  Plan on upgrading my computer (still rocking a 6th generation quad core i7, PC is still lightning fast with 64gb ram, was originally a music production computer), I want to get a 2nd RX7900XTX when I upgrade.  Get a 16 core Ryzen 9, 192gb RAM (main OS is Linux for gaming and general purpose using 4 cores and 64gb RAM, VM with Windows 10 or 12 when it comes out with 8 processor cores 64gb RAM for music production - this will quarantine my PC from Microsoft just move files I want to save onto shared drive and then away from drive into Linux so even as I play cat and mouse game with MS reenabling cloud each forced update, good luck deleting my files Microsoft without my permission (and that way I won't have to keep rebooting computer just to play with music software), VM for another Linux distro that is always running with 4 processor cores and 64gb RAM to use as a web browser to quarantine my computer from the internet as much as I can (sometimes I have had hundreds of browser tabs open as I go down crazy rabbit holes online sometimes)...go ahead and hack my virtual machine mr scammer).  I want my current 7900XTX on main monitor for both Linux distros, another 7900XTX for Windows VM on second monitor (and might as well get Games Ultimate pass while I'm at it, have some games I bought from MS store when I was running Windows before switching to Linux, might as well be able to play them at ultra settings).  This video card is a beast, glad people are walking away from Nvidia left and right, and AMD seems to have their act together between their amazing CPUs and these (in the past) underrated GPUs.  Will be a while before I can upgrade, can't wait!  I want those 3 OS's running every time computer is booted up.  Also external RAID storage and a small external Timeshift hard drive.  I'm a welder so a setup like that is very attainable, career in trades is a good income!  All hail Lord GaBen btw!!!
comments.author: @davidjeter5067

comments.text:
I'm trying to pick a GPU. I was wanting the 4080 super, but they simply aren't readily available- and when I can find them, they're almost as expensive as a 4090! Or... they're second hand. It's for VR (Virtual Desktop Quest 3 currently) and regular gaming (E.g., cyberpunk).
So, a question for Vex and the comments:
A refurbished 4080 super (£999 for a MSI X Slim)
A 7900 xtx (XFX model found for £820)
A 9070 xt (Between £655 and £740)
Other recommendation.
comments.author: @redwarrior864

comments.text: I'd personally go with the 4080 super if it's for VR, it has better features for that sort of stuff compared to AMD. The price of the 9070 xt is nice and the 7900 xtx is no joke either with it's 24 gb VRAM and is a great card but fps tests especially on VR shows nvidia is simply just better at VR no matter what.
comments.author: @Cigarette-y9c

comments.text:
@Cigarette-y9c  Problem is I can't find any 4080 Super that isn't either £1400+, refurbished or being sold on Ebay (don't trust).
At least one of the refurbished ones I've seen have a warranty, but it's still a used item for more money than a new item.
comments.author: @redwarrior864

comments.text: @redwarrior864  In that case I'd go for the 7900xtx due to the raw raster power and 24gb VRAM. I have the card myself and while I haven't played any VR on it I've seen many people say it can hold it's own in VR no problem and the tests match. The 9070 xt would be similar but lacks the VRAM you're going to end up using. I'd say look up some comparison videos and base it off what's actually in stock and not stupidly overpriced. (an nvidia card will be better in most cases for VR though, so it's really down to personal preference)

comments.text:
They didn't compare it to the 4070 super ti because they are going to release a 5070 super ti.  I mean come the fuck on; it's easily going to be 30% faster than the 4070 super ti; the 5070 ti is already 15% faster than the 4070 super ti.

This isn't a "next generation" release; 30% gains are fine, stop with the hyperbole.

I'd also love for you to run over to user benchmark and check your 9070 XT's real world performance to that of the 5070 12gb base model; because the base model is winning.  I also bought the 5070 base model for MSRP last week, so; yeah it's infinitely findable, start looking yourself instead of using that dumb ass website.  The Ray Tracing performance in the 5070 is better than the 4070 super.  I also want you to acknowledge that most games coming out in the near future are ray tracing only titles.  

Go look at your card in Doom The Dark Ages and compare it to the 5070 12gb.  It's losing.  You already did Indiana Jones; it lost there too.  Try Final Fantasy 16, loses again.  It's not going away.  AMD spent all of this effort to catch nvidia in rasterization; but nvidia read the tea leaves and said we need RT performance more.  Again, AMD is always playing catch up.

comments.text: I think what needs to happen to ensure that pricing actually means something is that reference cards need to exist. Outside of mining or scalping issues, the situation of AIB partners jacking up their cards beyond a reasonable level (e.g., $50 for an OC version for example, or +$75/$100 for a custom PCB design), the previous gens when this wasn't an issue there was always the reference design at MSRP with a stock cooler that could be purchased which forced AIBs to base off of that.

I just got a 12gb 5070 coz I does Sim Racing using a Quest 3 and my 12gb 3060 was starting to go funky, I am so glad I did get the 12gb 5070, A 250w GPU as well, Less chance of melted cables, Coz most cables are 300w, 250w shouldn't be an issue, But I am telling you now, I am impressed with the 5070, I have not gone out of 6gb of vRam doing AMS 2 in VR, No stutters, Graphics looks bad ass, And I did read AMD is not as good at VR as nVidia, But that is something I have read, I also heard the AMD cards are cheaper for a reason, lol, Joke by the way, But I am buzzing with my 12gb 5070, I am impressed with the vRam and being GDDR7, The next uplift from GDDR6, Not using no more than 6gb of vRam in AMS 2 with a fair few cars on track as well, I do not understand why people are moaning about the 12gb of vRam, To be only using 5.9gb of vRam when in VR using Steam VR, My 3060 would not even run Steam VR, lol, It is fast connecting the quest to my PC, a few seconds and I got my PC in my Quest 3, I still not tried games like No Mans Sky or Elite, But if the 5070 does sim racing so well I would imagine any other title would also do well, I can see a lot of kids getting a 5070 come Xmas time, lol, I am coming from a 3060 though so a 5070 is always going to look better in graphics ect, The 192bit goes in the 5070s favor, Brings me onto how other peoples experience of the 12gb 5070, What do other people think of the 5070 after using it.....
Gamers Nexus done a video about the 9070xt, I might check it in a bit, lol, I will say though the games do look alright on this GPU..
Years ago I was producing Hip Hop as a hobby, Saved hard for a AMD A8 PC, For production and damn it was slow, I had issues with the AMD, So since then I have been Intel, I even wonder if a 5070 would work better with Intel, Would an AMD CPU and AMD GPU have an advantage than if it was AMD CPU and a nVidia GPU?, Is AMD CPU and AMD GPU going to perform better purely coz it is AMD and AMD, daft question I know, But do mix match CPU and GPU going to effect what could be full performance, So Intel CPU an nVidia GPU goes better together, lol......
I am happy with the 5070, But I only do sim racing in the evenings, I am not a full on solid all day gamer, Still though I am happy with the 5070, And with it being a 250w GPU I never needed to upgrade my PSU, Though I am going to get an MSI 1000w, On Amazon they got some at good prices by the way, But yeah I have no issues with the 5070 myself, 80fps in VR smooth no stutters and looks fantastic, So yeah I am buzzing with the 12gb 5070......

comments.text:
I have gamed on a Steam Deck the last year. I have only just decided to become a REAL PC gamer at the beginning of 2025. I know, wrong time. 😂

I was looking at the GPU market and thought "why is this GPU $4,000 when it is supposed to be the already ridiculous MSRP price of $2,000?" I don't even want to pay $2,000 to build the entire PC.

As I have looked at the market and did my research, Ive actually developed a pretty negative opinion on Nvidia. I do have more favorable opinions on AMD. Since I am new I decided that I am just going to go budget. I'll be straight to the point...even the used GPU market has been terrible. I ended up doing the unthinkable. I didn't buy Nvidia OR AMD. I got the Intel Arc B580 with the Ryzen 5 9600x on a sub $200 deal. I think that CPU should help a bit with the B580's overhead issue that it still has. I think Intel might make a comeback from their terribly steamy CPUs with some cheaper GPUs that can compete at least on the budget side of PC building. I still don't have all the parts for the PC but we will see how it all turns out. I think it will be a decent 1440p experience with some up scaling and framgen on the most demanding games. I should be getting everything in a few weeks.

comments.text:
userbenchmark is trying its hardest to convinec people 9000 GPUs are a scam.

"If you are considering an AMD 9000 series GPU because you have been influenced by Reddit, Twitter or a wealthy tech YouTuber, it’s worth understanding AMD’s track record. While their GPUs are often great at beating cherry-picked benchmarks, they normally fall short in real-world gaming performance. Every year, an army of influencers target first-time buyers declaring AMD a godsend for PC gamers. Every year a small percentage of users get duped. Since almost all PC gamers use Steam, the February 2025 Steam statistics are relevant: AMD’s combined market share for discrete 5000/6000/7000 series GPUs is 3%. Meanwhile, Nvidia’s 4060 alone has 9% market share. This reality starkly contrasts with influencer hype. The reason is simple: influencers rarely play games and gamers rarely buy AMD GPUs. Experienced gamers know all too well that high average fps are worthless when they are accompanied with stutters, random crashes, black screens, excessive noise and a limited feature set. It’s notable that AMD’s GPUs have not historically had these problems in consoles because, unlike PCs, consoles operate in a closed environment which is less dependent on robust drivers. Using influencers for hardware performance data is less effective than using foxes to babysit chickens."

comments.text:
It's incredible how condescending you are towards AMD. When Nvidia outperforms it by 33%, instead of emphasizing and valuing that as much as you emphasize every obscure aspect you highlight when Radeon has better FPS, in Nvidia’s case, you downplay it and end up stripping it of its objective value and impact by saying things like “33% sounds like a lot, but it's much better than what AMD used to do.” I mean, are you kidding? Why can't you be objective? You're always sugarcoating things for AMD, unfortunately.

The reality is that AMD has only just now started stepping up and released a competent GPU—similar to what already existed in the RTX 3000 series—and now everyone acts like it's the greatest thing ever, forgetting that Nvidia still leads in ray tracing and upscaling quality by two generations. And nobody mentions that. It’s total misinformation, and people end up ignorantly falling for the false idea that AMD is better, which results in this dirty war in favor of AMD.

You should be clear so that when a consumer chooses to buy AMD, they know exactly what quality and performance they're losing in RT and how much they're saving in price for it. And yes, even with Nvidia's driver issues (which will get fixed) and other problems we don’t fully know the extent of, it’s still superior. The only real discussion should be: at what price is it worth it or not?

comments.text:
Yes, it's more insidious than before, largely due to the era of big data and new market segmentation strategies. In the past, price gaps between product lines were more pronounced, and consumers could clearly see where the best value for money was. Today, manufacturers leverage highly precise behavioral data to refine their pricing and segmentation strategies.

Why is it more devious today?

Algorithmic price optimization

By analyzing purchasing trends, manufacturers adjust their prices to maximize revenue. They know exactly how far an average consumer is willing to go in terms of budget before considering a product too expensive.

This results in minimal price differences between product lines, creating the illusion that a small extra cost grants access to a significantly superior model, even if the actual performance difference is marginal.

Anchoring effect and price perception

The "base" versions of products (like an RTX 4060 Ti) are sometimes deliberately underpowered to push buyers toward higher-end models.

"Fake choices" are also common: an RTX 4070 at $599 seems "reasonable" compared to a 4070 Ti at $799, which itself appears to be a good compromise against a 4080 at $1,199.

Marketing pressure and influencers

Manufacturers use tech influencers and media to shape consumer perception (e.g., "The RTX 4070 Ti is the sweet spot," nudging buyers toward that model).

Product launches are orchestrated to maximize hype and create the impression that an immediate purchase is necessary before stock runs out (FOMO – Fear of Missing Out).

The market for “forced” upgrades

Software advancements and game optimizations are often skewed in favor of newer hardware. For example, a game might be poorly optimized on an RTX 3000 series to push consumers toward an RTX 4000.

With DLSS 3.0, NVIDIA creates artificial software segmentation: RTX 3000 cards cannot use it, even though they are still very powerful.

Standardizing high prices

In the past, mid-range graphics cards cost $300-$400; today, they are $600-$700. By maintaining these high prices, manufacturers redefine consumer expectations, making the overall market more expensive.

Conclusion

It's more devious than before because everything is designed to steer the consumer without them realizing it. This is no longer just product segmentation; it’s a sophisticated manipulation using psychology, data, and algorithmic marketing to maximize average spending. The worst part is that since everyone plays along (manufacturers, influencers, media), it becomes very difficult to escape the cycle.

comments.text: Got a powercolor reaper rx 9070 16gb card for 580$ to replace my good old xfx rx 480 8gb gtr black edition. Undervolted it about 70mv and reduced the board power by 15% to use just 187w. Performs the same as stock, basically like a 7900xt but with much better ray tracing and using a fraction of the power - very efficient and performant. I could even go down to 154w and undervolt it further. But the powercolor reaper stock fans were faulty (unfortunately got a lemon). I deshrouded it instead of going for a return since besides them being grindy and noisy out of the box the chip and cooler itself were very strong (and I was eager to open the card up, check what they have on the mem and put some kryosheet on the core). So I attached 2x NF-A12x25 120mm fans I had to the card and now it is dead quiet and very cool. Under the biggest of stress the core sits at 60 C main reading and 74 C  on the hotspot and memory at 94 C at constant 40% fan speed (980rpm). Tried heavy raytracing, furmark, everything you can imagine, great thermal performance.

comments.text: For gaming, yes, AMD is a better deal, and of course that is the point of this video. For a few people like me, though, there is a definite point to Nvidia GPUs, because Nvidia GPUs turn into general purpose supercomputers, with their CUDA coding toolkit. With the right Nvidia card, I can game, of course, but I can also run a cutting edge reasoning LLM AI, like DeepSeek or QWQ, on my own computer! A used RTX-3090 ($1K), with its 24GB GDDR6X memory, lets the newest efficient AIs run entirely in its memory, with excellent performance, and I'm not giving my data to some corporation when I use them. The card name has to end with 90 to get 24GB -- 3090, 4090, 5090 --  but you can't really buy a working 5090 yet -- the practical choices are 3090 and 4090. After several years, AMD developed its own equivalent to CUDA, called ROCm, but it only runs on expensive Enterprise servers, not consumer GPUs. I would be stoked if AMD released ROCm for their gaming GPUs, but I have just heard about the SCALE toolkit from Spectral Compute, which supposedly lets you run CUDA code on an AMD GPU?

comments.text:
If you've already got a 4080S, 4090 or 5090 they aren't. If you don't care either way and just want the best of the best performance and don't care about price the 4090 and 5090 are still the best. Below that yeah, I would agree it doesn't make much sense to get the 50 series in general. If you can find a 4080S at MSRP now since the tariffs have made the 9070xt the same price there's an argument to go with the 4080S or the 9070xt it just depends on what you want. The tariffs are the main reason the 9070 and 9070 xt went up in price, so you can thank Trump for that one.

Both companies cards are overpriced still tbh. Even the 9070xt was a touch overpriced, better but still not super amazing. Compared to nvidia it's amazing but by itself it's not amazing. I personally have had a 7900 xtx and the cards drivers got less and less stable as time went on. It got to the point I got rid of it and bought a 4080S at MSRP and I'm going to be honest, I would 100% make the decision again. It got to the point with the 7900xtx that I had to constantly screw around with drivers and try to fix issues instead of just using my card. I had completely DDU'd the drivers MANY times and fresh installed etc and the driver would still crash at least once a day. So I had to pick between drivers that were stable or drivers that performed worse or had graphical issues and go back and forth between old and new drivers. So yeah, I bought AMD's highest end card and in the beginning it was fine but got worse as time went on and the 4080S for the games I play actually annihilated the 7900xtx at 100W less power. 

I have had mainly AMD gpus for most of my life, I've had 5 AMD gpus all the way back to the 7870 which is the card I bought for the first system I built myself, by comparison I've only ever had 2 nvidia cards, the 1070 and the 4080S so it's not like I am an Nvidia fan boy, I personally don't like any company, I like certain products from companies but I will drop any company or product for a better one or better priced one. I have no brand loyalty, if a product is good it's good, if it sucks it sucks. The 7900 xtx is the only card I had constant annoying issues with and it was the most expensive card I had ever bought at the time. Again it didn't start that way but it ended that way. So yeah, I can't fault someone for buying an nvidia card for drivers because from my personal experience over like 20 years of mainly having AMD GPUs, their drivers do kind of suck and they tried to run before they could walk with the 7900 xtx drivers to compete with nvidia and made the card itself less stable. I wasn't the only one with these issues, plenty of game forum posts and reddit post would complain of the same issue. I don't regret my decision to get rid of my 7900 xtx and get a 4080S and I got it for MSRP at the time. Now a yearish later I could still understand why someone would opt for the 4080S or 5080 (although you shouldn't bother with the 50s in general imo) over the 9070xt. I personally would still opt for the 9070xt if I were buying a card today.

comments.text:
As I hated Nvidia's business practices since the RTX 2000 series, I forever wished that AMD would give us any reason at all to buy their GPUs. Their raytracing performance meant some games would always be unplayable on them, and FSR was atrociously bad as well as open-source. I REALLY wanted to justify buying an AMD GPU, but when some games would randomly be unplayable for me due to poor ray-tracing, the price premium on Nvidia was always going to be worth it. The sad part is that, because Nvidia intentionally bottlenecks basically all of their "reasonable" cards with artificially low VRAM amounts, I was considering upgrading my 3060Ti to a 6090 when the time came. 9070 XT was like AMD heard all of my cries and personally responded to them.

I am currently on a 9070 XT and I could not be any happier that we are in this timeline now. Fuck Nvidia. Once we get an AMD version of Reflex 2, I am hopeful they will not be able to come up with yet another artificial bullshit like raYTrAciNg to make us pay for lazy developers and force unnecessary upgrades. I wish them the worst.

comments.text:
I have said it before and I will say it again: relying on upscalers on cards that consume more than 200W is a DNF. I am so done with comparing which upscaler looks less bad. Upscalers are a feature on handhelds where we are seriously constrained by battery capacity. But on a fully-fledged gaming system mandatory upscalers are just a crutch. Definitely not a feature. I would rather play at 1080p natively than 1440p with an upscaler.
Edit: Is AMD is able to offer FSR4 on their APUs then they will eat everybody's lunch in the portable market. That is until we manage to switch over to RISC architecture like Apple did.

I need to point out: Nvidia still has better latency to my knowledge.
Even without Reflex, Nvidia has marginally better input latency (though in that case, maybe not by a meaningful amount.)

Latency's the only reason (major) reason i'm sticking with nvidia, i'm just too sensitive to input lag. Not that i'd notice 2 or 3 Ms on their own, but 2 or 3 on top of another 2 or 3, on top of another, and another, and so on... It adds up. Plus, even if I don't notice it, it becomes less easy or comfortable to interface with the game.

Hoping AMD can do for input lag reduction what they did for upscaling.

comments.text:
AMD Cooked HARD on Navi 48. TBQH, I think keeping the hype set to a low simmer, helped with the reception of the cards. 
I ended up buying an XTX in Jan, after looking at the 'mid' performance leaks of Navi48 vs. my GRE that I had @ the time. Once the NDA was lifted on the 9070s, I realized I had made a 'mistake'. 
The RT performance improvements alone, are at least as large as RX6k->RX7k. NtM,  the memory subsystem on Navi 48 is so much faster, the 256-bit 16GB VRAM doesn't feel like an hindrance, even @ 4K.

Best part? 
Now that I'm running an RX 9070 XT instead of the 7900XTX, my rig doesn't hotbox me out and away from my desk after a few hours of gaming. 304-340W on the 9070 XT for 400-450+W of XTX-like performance.

comments.text: 22:00 This is why: CUDA. Many professional software suites, particularly on the engineering and science side, utilize the GPU performance by directly running (sometimes handwritten) CUDA code on the GPU hardware. CUDA is a really good GPU coding language, but proprietary to only Nvidia as it was invented by Nvidia (MATLAB is a great example of this in engineering and science). AMD kinda has an equivalent in OpenCL, but it’s not a true CUDA equivalent.

comments.text:
I have 9070XT already for a few weeks and I still very miss nvidia reflex support that makes today laggy UE5 games playable, also there are games from around 2018 that are still very demanding for native 4K on ultra and it supports only DLSS, so AMD yes and no, raw performance is a good thing, but unfortunatelly, whole industry is dominated by nvidia technologies and that's a problem. And AMD still didn't fix their drivers where not even basic settings like image scaling works. I set keep aspect ratio or integer scaler and it just doesn't work, so when I play old game that is 4:3, I have to disable GPU scaling and manually set 4:3 on my LCD which is pretty annoying and also it doesn't look native, I was very used to integer scaling on nvidia cards, why it doesn't work on AMD? I know, most of people don't buy such expensive GPU to play 20+ years old games, but if these settings are in drivers, it should at least work I would say, it's pretty annoying. But maybe it will start working after reinstall of Windows, we will see.

FSR and XeSS have very varied quality of implementation in specific games, in some games, it's like DLSS level of quality and in some other games (like Stalker 2), it looks pretty bad, like ofcourse it's usefull, but set it to ultra performance and you will see the difference compared to DLSS. Even with forced FSR 4 in Stalker and on performance or balanced, trees are kind of weird abd blurry. XeSS is better in this, but there are different problems, DLSS is just the best. But I guess when you have good enough raw performance and you keep FSR on quality or balanced, it's fine in the vast majority of games, but after another few years after my 9070XT will get weak, I will start missing possibility to set it to ultra performance with acceptable quality.
But for slightly older games that don't support some upscalers and reflex yet and still are demanding in native 4K, Radeon 9070XT is probably the best GPU to play these games.

BTW, today I tested Dying Light 2 on 9070XT and I almost cried, it runs in native 4K on ultra with ray tracing with like 90 FPS and it looks much better than some ugly Stalker 2, I am really sad. Yes, the game was pretty boring, but it was one of those last games where graphics/HW requirments ratio was still good, now it's gone and we have just UE5 lagging games with input lag like when I play from the Moon. The same WTF FPS in Kingdom Come 1 in native 4K, all settings on experimental and there is fkng 120 FPS, WTF is that? 😀  Only thing I just miss is reflex because with modern games, even 80 FPS still feels delayed and anti-lag does nothing. I found out that in UE5 games, there is tweak in Engine.ini file that completely removes input lag, but it causes massive FPS drops in some locations.
It's line r.OneFrameThreadLag=1 if someone is interested, set it to 0 and lag is gone, but in populated areas or in places with a lot of physics around, there is like 20 FPS drop, but it still feels better than high FPS and delayed mouse. But even without lag, moving in UE5 games still feels weird, mouse is acting not that great as in old games or other engines and no tweaks (like disable acceleration and stuff like that) make it better, it's just engine I guess, you can't make it better.

Yesterday, I was testing if those 2 8pins on 9070XT can burn my fingers and even after long time in a game, it's just warm, not literally cold, but I guess that pretty far from melting point, so better than nvidia I guess. 😀 I was thingking about 7900XTX, but I am fckng Nostradamus, so I can see that in the future, RT pefromance will be really important, I already predicted back in 2019 that to buy RTX card will be worthy even when ratio price/raw performance was not that good and people were calling me a fool for buying 2070 Super, but I survived 6 years with that GPU! I was right.

If there will be something like 5070 Ti Super for reasonable price, I will maybe sell my 9070XT to get more RT performance and DLSS/reflex support again, but I should not hope that there will be some 5070 Ti Super for reasonable price, but AMD is increasing MSRP and nvidia is vice versla slightly lowering it because they are scared of AMD I guess, so who knows, maybe it will get better after another few months. I am fool that I didn't buy 4070 Ti super duper when it was still for ok price.

17:11 - I actually recognized it correctly, DLSS 4 had slightly sharper and more detailed backpack in previous game, but there is 50:50 chance to guess correctly I guess. 😀

18:23 - it says it works in Stalker 2, but I pretty much don't see any improvement, so maybe it's not running and it's just fake green marker in drivers

And it's disingenuous to rag on Nvidia for not supporting the new frame gen when they DO support DLSS 4 all the way back to 20 series GPU's. FSR 3.1 performs worse than DLSS 4 and looks terrible and there is nothing you can do about it other than use optiscale to convert FSR to intel's Xess.  Which yields worse performance.  Gotta love spending 900$ on a 9070 XT because your favorite influencer grifted you only to find out it doesn't do what it says it does on the box and you have to resort to 3rd party paid programs to work around what AMD can't get working.

comments.text: DLSS is the pill for the disease ray tracing created.  AMD developed competing software, sure, but if Nvidia had just not ever decided that we "needed" real-time ray tracing, developers wouldn't be defaulting to it, we'd all be happily playing without it, and we would have never known how desperately we "needed" fake frames or upscaling.  They could still be around, but they'd be providing extra frame smoothness and/or higher apparent resolution instead of just eking out a playable FPS.  And graphics cards would be a lot less expensive.  In short, the artificial need for RT is ruining PC gaming.

comments.text:
I see bigger difference between FSR4 and DLSS4 than DLSS3 and FSR4. That said FSR4 does seem slightly better than DLSS3 so that is nice.
These RDNA4 cards would be absolutely amazing if AMD managed to make them along with FSR4 to compete with 40 series. Then FSR4 would be very strong compared to DLSS3 - also because back then Ray Reconstruction was not workable. Blackwell cards are not that big of an upgrade ovr Ada Lovelace and this helps RNDA4 a lot.

Otherwise being amazed you can have the same experience on AMD as on Nvidia... well, this is exactly how it should be. And this is how it was until Nvidia made quantum leap to RT and AI.
Generation after generation AMD lagged behind Nvidia with RDNA1 not even being DX12_2 capable. I had RDNA2 based 6900XT and performance was pretty good with RT and upscalers - giant disappointment. Intel provided workable upscaler XeSS DP4a while AMD gave us FSR2 which is... too ugly to be usable really.
It is even worse for RDNA3 because this architecture actually had decent ML/AI acceleration and it should allow at least DLSS3-like upscaler to be possible. AMD couldn't be bothered to make any ML based upscaler and reiterated FSR2 making it arguably worse... I mean removing ghosting by disabling upscaling of the parts of the image leading to even more pixelated look at places is not an improvement. Intel XeSS DP4a looks much much better. XeSS XMX looks even better. AMD could make at least something like XeSS XMX which uses RDNA3's AI accelerators to make it run as fast as FSR2/3.

Yeah, no comparison makes sense anymore because you need to take prices into account, and prices are all over the place. I was thinking about upgrading to 9070 XT from my 4070 Super, but at an 80% more of what I paid for the 4070 Super it would make absolutely no sense. And that price uplift is reality. Msrp is a myth, so if you bought your card 3 months ago, whatever you bought, hold on. It's not getting better anytime soon. 

Also, 12gb is quite ok on the 4070 Super. We need to put things in perspective. That's not a native 4k card, so the 12gb vram is not a constraint. If you play at 4k, as I do, you're upscaling from 1440p, and you're not cranking RT all the way up in any game. It's simply not that powerful a card. In conclusion - 4070 Super is a 4k dlssQ card and 12gb vram will never pose an issue. If for some reason it ever does, guess what - you lower the textures from ultra to high or something along those lines. None of the new cards are worth it, as simple as that, not at these prices.

comments.text:
Feels like a lot of people are having the same AMD moment I had with the 5870 in 2010 or something. The GeForce 8800 GTS was my last Nvidia card. Had two of them in SLI, but both broke and I was finally fed up with Nvidias bullshit. Been on AMD only since then and I have some thoughts on the current situation: 

* Raytracing has been a weakness for AMD since it existed, but on comparison videos it has rarely made an impact. And while tech YouTubers consider slightly better reflections as "huge difference", I usually couldn't even see it without zoom ins. So I ignored that. 

* AMD's upscaling has legit been better in the beginning (think CAS vs DLSS) and if you didn't 8x zoom ins on still comparison pictures, most of the time you wouldn't even notice the issues. 

* I'm surprised AMD actually bothered to improve the H264 encoder. That thing has legit been worse. Their AV1 encoder however has been good in the last generation already. 

Considering this plus the fact that AMD GPUs were almost always way cheaper and had the undervolting bonus for quite some time, I'm kinda smiling at the fact, that it took all this for some people to finalize realize, that AMD might actually be an alternative. For example: everyone smack talked the Radeon VII - I still bought it and was still running it up until recently. Had some serious horse power for its time and 16 GB. Ironically the YouTubers now crying about Nvidia GPUs having too little VRAM also complained about the Radeon VII having oversized VRAM, but it turned out that the oversized VRAM is, what kept the GPU alive. So for a GPU that was so so bad, it held up pretty well 😎

comments.text:
If you have an HDR-display and want to take advantage of HDR in most ways possible, then you can only go NVIDIA. You have 'RTX HDR' that works both in SDR games (both normal games and console emulators) and SDR videos (both in the web browser and locally stored videos) that makes any SDR games (from DirectX 9 and up) and SDR videos here to have HDR.

Same goes with 'RTX VSR'. If you watch any videos up to 1440p in resolution, they will be upscaled to a higher resolution. This also goes for any videos you watch in the web browser and any videos that is locally stored (up to 1440p).

And not to mention 'DLSS 4 Transformers'. Yes, 'FSR 4' is great, but 'DLSS 4 Transformers' are better. And that is proven many times to be true. And then we have 'Ray Tracing' and also the CUDA-cores that has its advantages on NVIDIA.

Why would I let go of those awesome features, just to save some money?

The problem is once you have gone HDR on most things (if you have an HDR-display), there is pretty much no way back.

If you can live without those features, then yes, the RX 9070 XT is a great GPU.

comments.text:
Here's the biggest problem the 5080 and above. They don't even really come close. It's not even a comparable comparison. The ray tracing is significantly more powerful and when you start getting into the higher end resolutions, the Gap grows even larger in performance differences and 1% lows. Dlss is significantly better looking than FSR and has better performance, frame gen on nvidia's graphics card perform significantly better than on AMD. The biggest problem that's not being talked about is developers and future games are heading towards overly relying on frame gen so you know what that means. As a customer for me, I'm going to buy whatever graphics card performs the best with everything it can use. If games are going to force me to use frame gen in the future, I'm going to use the card that has better frame Gen.  But saying that card compares to a 5080 is kind of insane. I've seen the side-by-side game comparisons of over 25 different games tested with it. In all resolutions. And high resolution AAA titles that don't even sit in the same room. I'm no Nvidia Fanboy. I'm not a fanboy for anything. I just bought my first PC. All I'm saying is comparing that card to the 5080 is so far from the truth. The entire reason the whole population is pissed is because in the high end 80 series and 90 series cards there is zero competition and that is the problem. Sadly this card is not competition on the high end. It's great. Mid to low high end. And good value.  Amd horribly needs to make a high-end graphics card. 

I feel like just in general mid-tier PC gaming is in a bad spot. The PS5 pro exists and has the performance of a 4070 TI . That is it's tested equivalent in GPU. If you're already compromising enough to go mid-tier, then the PS5 pro is the best option for price to performance in that category. For significantly less money than anything else you can make. That leaves extra money to buy a nice monitor or even a small OLED TV.  The way I look at it as I just upgraded myself from console. If you're going to pay PC money, you may as well get a high-end system for a few hundred more bucks. That or the PS5 pro. Xbox is also supposed to be releasing their new console next year. Mid-Range gaming has significantly too many options at way too wide of a price range. And high-end gaming is owned by one company. 2025 gaming sucks
comments.author: @XxkrazymagexX

comments.text:
What benchmarks? I have both and the 9070 XT is performing 5% better overall. A few games run faster on the 5070 Ti, others favor the 9070 XT. The difference is minimal.
In synthetic benchmarks (Furmark, 3Dmark) my 9070 XT is 5-10% faster than my 5070 Ti, making me wonder where you have your numbers from.

Also about ray tracing: the RX 7000 series has very slow RT cores. The 9000 series cores are about 2.5x faster however, making them slightly faster than the 5070 Ti. I've tested this in DirectX 12 and Vulkan using an unoptimized ray acceleration structure for reflections and global illumination. I've also tested my 7900 XTX again while I was at it, which was about 60% behind the 9070 XT in raw RT performance.
comments.author: @doktoruwu

comments.text:
@doktoruwu  Most benchmarks come to a +5% conclusion for the Ti over the XT
when 50+ games are considered.
This is basically what all big testing channels usually end up with.

the 20% difference is in the low 1%, not the average FPS. if the XT has the lows at 40, and the Ti at 48, that's the 20% difference. (edit: seems like 20% was too high, it's more like +5-15% for the 1% lows)

Wether it's Gamernexus, Hardware unboxed or the German channels I usually watch.
These are all respected hardware testers and usually where people look at

There are some few exceptions like SM2 or Rocket League which runs poorly on the Ti, but the overall bulk seems to run "worse" on the XT (but still great for the price difference). The XT has quite a few games where it runs poorly as well, like GTA5, ACC, Hunt Showdown etc.

And while AMDs RT is better than ever, it's still far behind Nvidea's. This too is also readily available information, but as mentioned, most people probably don't even use RT and see it as a gimmick.

comments.text:
Finally, A reviewer that actually compares the software side. I think that if the price situation clears up the clear choice is the 507ti. Simply more mature support for AI, rendering, interoperable DLSS,, ability to use FSR if needed, up scaling, ray tracing, nvenc encoding, future potential DLSS type upgrades as it ages (see 2000 series getting DLSS4), future resale value and it has the market share to give devs incentive to optimise for it.  
Not saying the 9070XT is a bad product and I am all for competition but if you use your PC for anything other than just 1080/1440 raster gaming the choice is the 5070ti. I sold my 9070XT that I got on release as sure the FPS in MH wilds is great but everything else I "needed to do" that required GPU acceleration was just 'sub par' - even compared to a 3070Ti. 

It's the iPhone vs android argument, sure the android has double the ram but the integration and software experience for the most is better and once you experience that you cant come back.

Appreciate that your review looked at more than just bar graphs and gave a holistic view. Now all we need is for the prices to fix its self. Right??
comments.author: @DharshanRasiah

comments.text: forgot to mention reflex, video super resolution, more than 2x frame gen, broadcast camera / mic filtering, physx. And to add to all this the ability to actually use an older RTX card in position 2 to offload all these secondary rendering, encoding processing tasks to while keeping the main nvidia GPU free to render games. I tried this with the 9070XT in position 1 and 3070TI in position 2 and this was simply not possible due to the driver limitations of both adrenalin and nvidia app wanting to take priority, killing the performance of the 9070XT. Works fine with 2x nvidia cards (3070ti main,  2070 support) but not 1x amd and 1x nvidia (9070XT main, 3070ti support). I know they never designed it to do that but it means you can keep old cards out of e waste working as a co processor reducing strain on the main gpu.
comments.author: @DharshanRasiah

comments.author: @fizz9698

comments.text:
@aranyrigo1871  Your CPU and GPU both get fed specific voltages, which are predefined by the manufacturer. Wattage = Volt x Ampere. If you manage to lower the voltage, you can run the specific component with much  less wattage and thus less heat, ergo the component is able to boost to higher clocks,  due to previously removed thermal limitations.
If you open up the BIOS or the GPU driver suite,  you can tweak that voltage, by lowering it step by step. For every step you have to  evaluate that the component still runs stable. After youve found the lowest voltage value at which the component still runs stable, youre almost done. In case of your GPU, just raise the available TBP to +10% via the slider in the AMD Adrenaline suite - boom: Insane perfomance increase  for free. Only downside is that the cooling solution of the card might not be able to deliver silent performance anymore.
comments.author: @Blumenfreund84

comments.text:
@matthewsalmon8194  AMD GPUs are total board power limited. Unlike nVIDIA, AMD places restrictions on power consumption. AMD uses this to then be able to gauge how much boost the card can attain while fitting within power restrictions. If you undervolt your GPU, you lower the total board power consumption, which allows the GPU to have more power available to it to boost higher. That's how it works.

It's a delicate balance as if you overclock the VRAM, raising the VRAM power consumption, your GPU won't boost as high and you may experience lower performance. Derbauer ran into this and was scratching his head as to the cause, well... there it is.

It's been this way at least since the Radeon VII.

There are registry hacks you can implement to bypass these power restrictions, at least there were with Vega and Radeon VII, not sure on the 5000. 6000. 7000. and now 9000 series. I did remove the power restrictions on my Radeon VII, pushing power consumption to over 450W. I custom watercooled the card and it was able to beat a RTX 2080. Anyway, that's how AMD Graphics cards work.

comments.text: @SimplCup  8 and 16k textures....just say you know absolutly nothing about software and hardware and stop spreading your imagination...new games dont use 8k textures, they need more vram because they use more unique textures that dont get repeaded that often in the game world...best example is a forest in a game, in older games you where able to go in to the forest and spot the same tree over and over again because the textures got reused, newer games dont do that so you need more vram to store all this different trees and bushes...and the lack of performance on pc in this newer games comes mostly because of the fact, that a pc has to bruteforce its way because its lacking dedicated texture decompression hardware so it has to be done on the cpu or gpu wich eats tonns of performance and microsofts "direct storage" is just a gimmick on pc wich doesnt work nearly as efficient and fast as dedicated decompression hardware.

comments.text:
Fsr4 is garbage for 2 reasons:
1. Only 90xx series is getting it while NV cards have better scaling since the 30xx series. 
2. FSR4 only goes to the newest games while DLSS has been there for ages.
There is no reason to buy AMD now unless you only play the newest games and don't replay anything older.
People should just go for 2nd hand 40xx series, it's the best value now. Or 6800/7800 for those sweet 16gigs of vram and laugh at 9070xt with its relative performance +30-40% with +80% price.
comments.author: @batonnikus

comments.text:
@ I mean it's not garbage. It's an excellent upscaler. The only one better is DLSS 4, which was released two months ago. You're being insanely dramatic. 

You literally can't buy second hand 40 series cards at a cheaper price than 50 series cards right now in a lot of cases. They stopped manufacturing them. 


Lastly, the older the game is, the less likely you even need upscaling, for multiple reasons. Games were less demanding, and they were less reliant on upscaling tech to provide clean image quality. 

Your whole post is very silly. Yes FSR 4 needs to be integrated into more games, and it will be. It's certainly an advantage for DLSS for the time being, and for a while moving forward. It's still far better than what they previously offered, and this was their only route forward. It's a fantastic first step.
